Rather shocked how fun and good this game is for as simple as it is.

2d fighter based on real life styles and some semi fictional.  It's mortal Kombat without fire balls, teleporting or ice spears.  It's a very grounded 2D fighting game in an arcade style. 

The music is fun, game creates a good atmosphere, controls are very simple and game play is good yet simple as well.  Even those who suck at fighting games can get good at this.  Small learning curve, well done game, and looks very appealing.

38641645.review:
How can anyone not love this game?  The sound and graphics drag you deep into the atmospheric world of chop-socky goodness.  A broad selection of superbly realised fighters from different traditions makes every fight a thing of beauty.  Especially with the 70's style filters on :)

Controls for all characters are the same, with punch/kick/weapon/dash buttons that are used in conjunction with directional movements, some double button presses, and quarter-circle movements.  This gives you "soft/normal/hard" attacks, a throw, and a few other things.  The animation and hitboxes have been lovingly tailored to each individual style, and logical sequences and combos are possible - and different for each fighter.  It all works very well, and feels nice and solid.

If, as seems to be the case, development is still going on and more bits (More character story?  More fighters to join the current 27?  More modes to join the ones that are already in there?) are going to be added in the future then this should make things even more appealing to any fight fans out there.

38556516.review:
Já começo dizendo que eu recomendo para quem é fã das artes marciais chinesas mesmo!

Sou praticante de Kung Fu, não sei tudo obviamente, mas tenho que elogiar a fidelidade de movimentos com estilos reais de kung fu e ainda mais com a pegada Wutang. Ficou muito fiel aos clássicos da tão amada Golden Harvest, entre outras.
Um jogo bem focado aos amantes de artes marciais, especificamente chinesas, pois alguns outros estilos no jogo estão deixando a desejar.
Infelizmente tem uma certa lentidão na tela inicial de carregamento, demorando as vezes o mesmo que o meu GTA V e com certeza o jogo não é nem 5% do mesmo, e as vezes rola um bug de inversão de comandos no controle entre cima e baixo.
Cenários ficaram muito bons.
Personagens precisam ser refinados, os movimentos ainda são muito travados e as vezes com delay... sem falar das defesas que parecem ser na sorte.
Apesar de tudo, gostei muito da ideia de fazer "Shaolin vs Wutang", foi sensacional, eu apoio uma continuação, mais trabalhada, com um pouco mais de paciência, sei que não é fácil produzir um jogo, mas faltou um pouco mais de "brilho" nessa versão, posicionamento de cameras para o foco dos personagens e seus ataques.

Repetindo... recomendo para os fãs mesmo de Kung Fu, fora isso, vai perder a cabeça e pedir o dinheiro de volta!

致敬80年代香港功夫片的格斗游戏。
游戏中的角色均出自经典香港功夫电影，比如：李小龙、成龙、李连杰、甄子丹、刘家辉等等，游戏中的场景、音效和招式也都完美还原，可以在游戏中看到熟悉的截拳道、醉拳、蛇鹤双形、咏春、少林罗汉拳等等，特别是超必杀的镜头慢放和音效让人热血沸腾。游戏现在还处于EA阶段，并且作者一直在更新角色和场景，目前可选择25个角色和24个场景。美中不足的是作为一款格斗游戏不支持联机对战。

38295838.review:
Lets be clear, this game is not the greatest game graphically and lacks refinement in input commands.  It is not even close to being as enjoyable as DOA 5, Tekken 6, BlazeBlue, or Street Fighter IV.  It has only basic inputs, like 12 total moves for each character, is 2D only, and is not what i consider to be a fighting game on par with the great games like i mentioned already.  

However, I love Kung Fu movies alot.  I mean alot.  Love the importance of scenery, love the stereotypes Kung Fu movies all share as standard practice (the village idiot who is always prophetic, the womanizing-good natured friend who always gets injured or dies, the dark art master villans, the Shailon Temple monks who never seem to do the right thing morally, the evil Japanese lord, the rich Chinese merchant who is always showing off and looking like an idiot, the fat chinese man who always wants to start the revolution, the quite yet strong village woman who is the epitome of perfection and never ever is shown in any way other then reverance, the flawed master of kung fu and the wise master who teaches, and even the brazenly loud mouthed, typically huge American who most likely will have killed some lesser known Chinese master before being dealt with by the hero of the movie.  

Love the glimpses of culture, the way they eat, the importance of hierachy and most importantly the kung fu.  

So i find myself playing this game so i can see some fairly accurate kung fu styles competing against one another.  It is something else seeing a generic Bruce Lee pit his Jet Keen Do against IP Man's Wing Chun or Jackie Chan's drunken fist take on Jet Li's Wushu style.   Other styles include American Karate, Lotus Blossum, Buddhist Palm, Tawainesee Wrestling (think the bad ass villian of all Claude Van Damme movies) and Shaolin.  All charactors are recognizable as the people who made the discipline famous like say Bruce Lee, Jackie Chan, Donnie Yen, Jet Li, the 70's African American who was a student of Bruce Lees (cannot remember his name now), and some more obscure non mainstream actors circa the 70's that are almost impossible to watch.  

Greatest Kung Fu Movies in my opinion starting with my number one favorite.

1 - Fist of Legend (Jet Li)
2 - Kung Fu Hustle (Stephen Chow)
3 - Tai Chi Master (Jet Li)
4 - House of Flying Daggers (Ziyi Zhang)
5 - IP Man 2 (Donnie Yen)
6 - IP Man (Donnie Yen)
7 - Enter the Dragon (Bruce Lee)
8 - Grand Master (Ziyi Zhang)
9 - Fearless (Jet Li)
10 - Azumi (Ava Ueto)

The only thing missing in the game is a Tommie Ja (Ong Bach, The Protector).  

Shaolin vs Wutang gets a solid 7 out of 10 only cause i am such a dork.  Otherwise it would get a 5 out of 10 for its lack of moves, lack of refinement, and rigid movements.

36609236.review:
Still early on in my gameplay so this is a short review for now:

Game came out of nowhere! Appeared on my Steam recommended, had a look around on the forums and was pleased to give it a go. Glad I did. The game is awesome! 

A quick rundown of what I've seen so far:
- 24 unique characters with amazing attention to detail in technique & style.
- Arcade, Tournament, Versus, Survival, good selection of modes.
- Player vs Player, Player vs CPU, CPU vs CPU with HP Handicaps (0-10).
- 24 well crafted stages.
- Great soundtrack & voice over work, really captures the vibe.

If you're a fan of 60s - 90s Kung Fu Flicks & like fighter games, then this is a good fit.

£9.99 well spent I reckon. Will update my review as time goes on.

36378535.review:
Bought this on a whim the other night when I saw it on sale (and cos I'm a sucker for Kung Fu flicks) and have to say this is great.

It's a budget title and the Developer says "It is not my intention to provide the same experience as big budget fighting games" but they've pretty much nailed it. It is obviously more simplistic than the AAA fighters, but in many ways that makes it more accessable and gives it a real pick up and play vibe. Basically, someone who rarely plays fighting games will get their head around this in minutes and have fun, so its great for parties.

Its fast enough to keep most purist happy too, and if they moan about a 'lack of depth' or such, just remind them that this is four times cheaper than Tekken 7, and that game doesn't have the late great Jim Kelly in it 'looking good'.

35732812.review:
TL:DR This game is easy fun and the best money I have ever spent on a fighting game. 

JaeLee is a one person army who is giving Capcom and SNK and Sega a run for their money.


Long version

This game is extremely customizable both graphically, in terms of difficulty level, and in terms of the game play.  All the basic moves are availabe in an in game help screen and very useful. 

GRAPHICS :
There is a basic graphics level screen with a low to high pc scale setting and resolution, and a more advanced settings screen for those who want to poke around and customize. There is also one grahical setting "Battle Damage" in the games settings screen which I recommend turning off if your fights lag.

DIFFICULTY

OPPONENTS:
There are five difficulty levels for all game modes  and a customizable handicap for certain non-arcade modes. 

LEARNING CURVE FOR MOVES:
You can watch the ai characters  play on any difficulty level to learn moves that aren't in the help screen. There is a completely customizable training mode where you can try out your character's moves against a customizable ai opponent (either stands still, does a certain move or fights). All the moves that aren't documented in game are easily and intuitively learnable in the training mode. There is also a lot of documentation of moves and combos in the steam thread. This has become my favoirte fighting game of all time because the system is so intuitive and well designed. 


GAMEPLAY CUSTOMIZATION (REPLAY VALUE)
The difficulty level ramps up as your skill improves which, combined with the different play modes ensures many hours of fun replay even after new content stops being added (as of this post new content, happily, appears to still be in the works).

COMMUNITY & DEV SUPPORT
 Apart from the  stream of new and relevant content, the user community is friendly and the developer is diligent in answering new questions and patient with newbies..

This game when I first saw footage of it, got me excited like the golden era fighters, it really feels like that. At the same time, it also has a new game sorta vibe, it's very fresh in the movement and play, so when I say golden era I don't mean it plays like an old game. This is tough to put to words.

It plays like an arcade classic. In its current form, it has a tournament mode.

Game has a ton of charactors, ton of moves, killer stages, awesome music. I can't begin to imagine what the final completed game will be like.

This game is a 4 button fighter with directional movement to adjust hit strength. A lot of crazy combo possiblities and exciting action when you are really getting in there.

If you are a fan of classic (also golden era) Kung Fu films, and you are into fighting games, this could be the one.

33926709.review:
Emotionally this game gives me what no other has.  I literally sat there cackling with delight the first time I was on the character select screen.  Great presentation, animations, theme, characters, etc.  A true homage to the films of my youth.

Then I got into the fight portion.  Oh boy.

Seems the focus is all on having each character perform outrageous moves in line with each's individual kung fu style, with almost no care put into the GAME aspect.  I couldn't find any reason to do one move vs. a different move.  I don't see any kind of actual combat logic under the surface.

Clunky combos that don't really "work" and characters have *way* too many animation frames.  I'm sorry but in a fighting game I don't really see the advantage to a 75 frame wind-up of a move that can not ever actually hit the opponent.

I also don't see the need for 120 frames of animation for a guy to pass guard or feint.

I will buy this again in maybe a year.  Possibly two.  But for now I want my darn money back because strip away the glitzy presentation there really isn't a fun game underneath.

33834569.review:
Okay, I've played over 5 hours on this game and I only bought the thing 5.5 hours ago. The first hour was me laughing like a maniac as the game flooded my senses with martials arts movie themes. This is a fun kung fu fighting game which delivers all of the movie nostaligia from martial arts cinema. An impressive variety of kung fu styles are represented by unbespoke characters who slightly resemble certain people of fame in a related industry.

The controls are quite basic - using an XBox One controller there is no function for the triggers or LB/RB buttons. The game played fine on my ageing i7 + 980GTX + SSD system with graphics cranked up to max.

Backgrounds and character details are lushious with martial arts postures of each character tuned to very fine detail. The music also draws you in again bringing that nostalgia right back again. 

I also love the fact that the character design isn't exaggerated. There's no excessive and obtrusive boob wobble on the female characters. All characters are as if they were pulled straight out of their respective movies when at their peak.

I would have liked to have seen more variety of combos for each character but this game already ticks so many boxes in my childhood martial arts fighting game wish list I can live with the foibles in this incredibly affordable and entertaining game. 

The game is best played with a controller though apparently it is possible to play using keyboard controls. Good luck executing combos that way though.

At the time of writing this I am about 7 characters into completing the game with each character and the only reason I stopped is because I need to rest my thumbs...and sleep...and work the next day. Yeah, they're kind of important.

Despite it not being a complex game I will likely keep coming back to it long after I've completed the achievements. Probably the most fun game grinding experience I've had in a while.

If you're a martial arts fan/movie buff, particularly Hong Kong cinema, this is definitely worth your consideration and as good a reason as any to go and buy a controller.

33272752.review:
Pros:
       Effectively Captures 80s and 70s martial arts films
       One of the most accurate representations of Bruce Lee in any fighting game
       Combos feel satisfying to pull off.
       Weapons Integration is a nice touch.
       Immersive blocking system.
       Great level music that really captures the period...

Cons:

Rough around the edges with some visual glitches and unpolished audio w/weird voice packs (some chars don't sound like they have their own voice).
       
AI is mostly non-aggressive and do not use combos often.  They also seem to back down when you pour your offense on them (even on the highest difficulty levels).  More aggressive and challenging AI will increase longevity (though what's here is fine to get the hang of how things play)

Mobility is an issue (moving in and out of striking range easier/quicker for higher level play would be appreciated).  Would also appreciate the ability to quickly recover from falls to keep the action moving.



Gameplay video:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MOs04cz3FYc

All considered, this is a game that deserves support and in a number of ways, moves fighting games in the right direction.  It's not a polished masterpiece and there are the rough edges you'd expect from an indie title, but it's so much fun to be this well-realized version of Bruce Lee (a selling point all its own).  

Recommended to all fans of the genre.. especially at a price of around 6 bucks.

33250057.review:
The love that went into creating this game is unbelievable.  If you like new or old kung-fu flicks you are doing yourself a disservice by not picking up this game. 32798954.review:
个人还是很喜欢邵氏电影的，同时也喜欢尝试各类格斗游戏。
所以当看见这《少林VS武当》的时候，正好碰上夏促打折，毫不犹豫就买了。
平心而论，游戏中各个角色都能有电影原型，着实让人感动。但……作为格斗游戏而言，太不及格了……
手感很差，攻击判定很迷，连技系统也做得不好，还有其他的一些小问题。讲真，如果这些放到其他格斗游戏中基本就是挂了。
不过我还是耐着性子通了一遍街机模式，同时也测试了几个感兴趣的角色。

然后就选择退款了……

所有的角色招式都是通用的输入方式：↓→+攻击或↓←+攻击，为了简略我用字母代替P（拳）K（踢）W（武器）。
不过最让人不爽的是，有些角色，↓←或↓→+攻击是没有招式的。（对，我说的就是忍者你，你竟然只有↓→+W这么一招必杀技……其他都是空档，很多角色都是如此，只有那么1或2招必杀技，然而出招表连区分一下都没有）一些角色的招式也很有既视感，例如白眉的近身投技让我想起了铁拳6里LEO的近身投技。

我用的360手柄和键盘进行测试，输入实在是太迷了，根本不知道怎样才能正确输出一个必杀技，有时候↓→狂搓了半天角色就是原地站着攻击而已。斜跳也神奇得很，有时候行有时候不行，一度让我怀疑手柄坏了。

还有很多想吐槽的，鉴于已经退款了就不多说了。最后分享一个目前发现的比较实用的连技：
角色咏春（叶问-甄子丹）：跳K、站P、站P、→+P、→+P、站K、站K、→+K、→+K、↓→+P
一次可以有12-13Hit，差不多能打半管血，几乎所有对手都能打PERFECT。我就是这么通关的，屡试不爽。可惜分数只有218990，没上20名。

希望评测对你有帮助，当为情怀买单的，个人很推荐。当格斗游戏来玩的。你还是最好别买了。

32652357.review:
This game is a wonderful compilation of some of the greatest homages to martial arts films of old. The music and stages together with many unique fighters combine to create a very unique experience unavailable elsewhere in the genre. It comes with the full barrage of game modes expected in a fighter (Arcade, Survival, Team Battle, Training) and a Tournament mode for extra fun.

   The controls for this game are simple (Punch, Kick, Weapon, Dash) and are easy to string together to create combos in the system using directional modifiers (Ex: P,P,P, --> P, K, K, --> K, <-- K). As nearly all 2D fighters it features quarter circle specials, supers, throws, and blocking by holding back. Where it excels is how easy it is to start doing cool things right away. Unlike its predecessor (Kings of Kung Fu) it is very responsive and you will not find yourself battling against the controls. The AI is very forgiving at easier levels and presents a decent challenge at higher levels.

   If you have ever enjoyed watching martial arts films with stars like Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan, you definitely owe it to yourself to check this gem out. It is a whole lot of fun, especially if you ever get together with a bunch of friends and play the Tournament mode!

31496595.review:
shaolin vs wutang is not your typical fighting game. visually, it's pretty good to look at; from the characters, to the moves, this will definitely remind you of the old kung fu movies from the 70s or 80s. on top of which, the dev has even put in background music from those movies itself! so in terms of both the audio and visuals, this game will definitely take you back to another era, and in that sense, it's very well done.

if you're looking for a competitive fighter however, the likes of street fighter, or king of fighters, or guilty gear, etc. then just maybe you're looking at the wrong game. the controls here feels a bit more loose, and personally, reminds me a lot of games such as say ... mortal kombat I perhaps. not entirely refined, but sufficient for a casual gamer who wants to jump into a fighter, without worrying too much about over-elaborate combos and all that.

the moves available to each character is unique, and fun to look at, especially if you do manage to pull off a decent combo string. the commands however, are identical across the board for all characters it would seem, but again, this would suit a casual gamer too, as they wont have to memorize a whole ton of different commands, but instead just pick the fighter they like best, and still could execute their moves without problems.

all in all, this is a fairly unique fighter. it's a lot of fun, even for myself who have spent over 20 years playing the likes of street fighter, king of fighters, tekken, etc. i really do like the nostalgic trip down memory lane, and that i dont have to overthink things playing this.

besides, where else are you gonna pit donnie yen against jackie chan or bruce lee? highly recommended for fans of those old kung fu flicks, as well as anyone who wants to pick up a more casual fighter. looking forward to what other polishes and add-ons the dev will throw at it on full release.

平衡性：由于没和其他玩家PK过， 所以平衡性方面不好评价。
指令设计：应该是采用多段式，每段有犹豫时间来等待玩家输入的方式来做的。因此操作起来很容易上手，要加分~
连段设计：有点迷糊。。大部分情况下，我只能看hit数来判断自己连上了没，但我认为一款好的格斗游戏应该能让玩家能够直观的判断自己的连段是否成功，因为在激烈的对战中，要时时观察hit数是挺难受的事情。
策略性：由于薄弱的空战系统，没有牵制技能和破防系统。可以预见作为FTG这款游戏的立回方式是十分有限的（基本就是上下择和抢招）。这一点也可能是作者有意为之，毕竟是独立游戏，不做太多系统不失为一个好选择。
AI 设计： 很弱。。。即使极难的电脑也不会防空。。。不会切防。。。因此上下择，左右猜可以完虐电脑。。
综合以上几点，游戏性方面只能三星了~

总体来说，这还是一款十分棒的独立游戏，高还原，易上手，你值得拥有~

31372984.review:
This is one of those games I wish I could leave a neutral recommendation for. Not an upvote, nor a downvote per se. 

It's not a terrible game, but it's not a great game either. I guess because it is early access this is to be expected. I mainly purchased it because I love classic Kung Fu cinema, and easily get the references in characters, soundtrack, etc... Thought it would be fun to have in my collection and play around with. 

It's actually pretty decent for a 1 man developed game. But if you are looking for a solid fighting game, I'd look elsewhere for something with more polish. This one is just passable right now. It still needs a lot of tweaking and balance. And since it is just a 1 man team, I'm sure this will be a slow process. 

As of the time of writing this you have a decent sized roster of combatants, with single and offline multiplayer, and a decent selection of stages and a few modes of traditional play. 

Where the game is having issues though that I hope might be tweaked would be the stiffness of moves, lack of diversity in pulling off secials, and other minor annoyances. Every character I have tried has the same list of required inputs to pull off specials, which all stem from quarter circle moves. No variety. There are also throw moves, and "supers" which are earned when filling up a meter. The "super" moves are all short in animation, and all performed the same way. This really gives the player zero incentive to practice the exeuction of moves for every character. I hope this is something that is fixed later on. 

In any case, I do love the homage to classic Kung Fu cinema. You have a good roster of fighters featuring mock ups from various movies including characters like Pai Mei, Beggar Su, The Drunken Master, Bruce Lee, and many others. Each with their own fighting style that I hope is expanded upon. 

Bottom line, if you like classic Kung Fu movies in the vein of Shaw Brothers, Golden Harvest and others, give this one a look. However, if you want a competent fighter to stand up to the likes of the Street Fighter, King of Fighters and Guilty Gear types of games, I'd probably avoid this one.

29547369.review:
Ce [i]Shaolin vs Wutang[/i] chopé soldé à 6,5€ sur un coup de tête est plutôt riche en contenu et déjà bien sympa pour une early access! Et ma foi, je ne regrette pas de lui avoir lâché cette poignée d'euros. 

Possédant déjà [i]"Kings of Kung-Fu"[/i] (jeu précédent du même développeur [i]Jae-Lee[/i]), difficile de ne pas les comparer tant le propos et la réalisation des deux jeux semblent en tous points similaires au 1er abord... Y compris dans certains de leurs défauts. C'est parfois tellement identique qu'on pourrait presque parler d'un "Kings of Kung-Fu 2". Mais heureusement, ce [i]Shaolin vs Wutang[/i] me semble beaucoup plus abouti et mieux finalisé que son aîné - qui n'était probablement qu'un brouillon d'essai... 

Le gameplay utilise uniquement les 4 boutons de façade + le stick (ou la croix) directionnel(le). Je n'ai personnellement joué qu'au Pad 360 - même si il est apparemment possible de jouer au clavier.
Chaque personnage dispose naturellement d'un bouton "punch" et "kick" déclinable en puissance légère, moyenne ou forte, en fonction de l'orientation du stick. (+ une traditionnelle chope).

Nouveauté par rapport à l'opus précédent : Chacun dispose désormais aussi d'une arme propre à son style, utilisable avec un 3e bouton (et variant également ses combos en fonction des manipulations du stick).
La 4e touche est étrangement dédiée aux déplacements rapides (roulades avant, flip arrière, et pour passer dans le dos de l'adversaire) - la parade quant à elle s’exécute en maintenant le stick en position arrière, comme dans les Street Fighter.

Autre emprunt à la franchise de Capcom: Des coups spéciaux stylés et efficaces sortiront avec des quarts de cercles avant ou arrière. (Mais fort heureusement, toujours pas de boules de feu ni rien de "surnaturel" - ce qui permet de bien respecter l'esprit des films auxquels le jeu rend hommage.)
De plus, une nouvelle jauge fait son apparition, qui, une fois remplie (à force de prendre des baffes ou d'en distribuer), permettra d'enclencher un mouvement d'attaque spécial sctipté (un peu comme les "Ultras" dans S.F.4), tandis qu'une autre combinaison de boutons permettra aussi d'user d'un "combo braker", utilisant cette même jauge.

Globalement, tout sort relativement bien et facilement, à quelques rares exceptions près. Ce gameplay 2D simple fonctionne, et s'avère très vite assimilable pour enchaîner les (nombreux) combats du mode arcade. Précision : Le jeu ne dispose que d'un versus LOCAL uniquement - PAS de versus online. D'autres modes sont cependant disponibles : training, survival, team battle, tournament.

Le jeu propose d'incarner 19 personnages, tous issus de films de kung-fu asiatiques cultes des années 70/80. (On fermera les yeux sur la présence bienvenue de Ip Man dans ce rooster, bien qu'il soit anachronique, puisque le 1er film avec Donnie Yen - ici clairement représenté, date de 2008).
Si comme moi votre enfance/adolescence a été bercée par la douce violence de ces productions Hong-kongaises, c'est avec grand plaisir que vous retrouvez divers protagonistes très fidèlement modélisés, jusque dans leur costumes... Siu Tien Yuen et Hwang Jang-Lee sont identiques à leurs personnages dans "Snake in the Eagle's shadow", Bruce est là, sortant de temps en temps un coup sifflant de nunchaku, et Jackie picolera sa bouteille de jaja toujours bien à l'aise en imprévisible Drunken Master. Si on peut regretter l’absence de "pointures" comme Sammo Hung, le casting est déjà très bien fourni.

Côté réalisation, les animations sont extrêmement fluides et fidèles aux styles de combats représentés, c'est un vrai bonheur de les voir s’enchaîner de façon très naturelle.
Mais graphiquement, les similitudes sautent aux yeux avec "Kings of Kung-fu". Si le jeu est en net progrès sur le plan esthétique, les décors restent cependant inégaux - certains étant nettement plus réussis que les autres. Mais la modélisation des personnages est plus propre et travaillée, et on sent un certaine volonté d'amélioration par de petits détails - comme l'intégration d'objets cassables dans le décor par exemple...

Bel effort également sur les bruitages et les musiques, une fois de plus étonnamment fidèles à celles des films représentés! [i](J'écris "étonnamment", car je m'interroge vraiment sur la question des "droits" précisément relatifs à ces musiques, à ces films, ou à l'image de ces acteurs qu'on reconnaît immédiatement, qui me paraissent utilisés complètement illégalement par ce minuscule studio indé... Mais bon ; je ne vais pas m'en plaindre).[/i]

L'interface en revanche reste absolument ignoble : image de bibliothèque hideuse, menus bien tartignoles de l'écran titre aux options, en passant par les typos un peu pourries... Le design est vraiment pauvre de ce côté là.
(Puisqu'on en parle, les options sont relativement modestes mais proposent l'essentiel, notamment une liste des mouvements plutôt bien faite et illustrée aux couleurs des boutons du pad 360 : plutôt cool).

On peut aussi lui reprocher quelques bugs, quelques ralentissements, son temps de chargement initial un poil longuet, le mix de certains bruitages trop forts par rapports aux autres (ceux des objets qui se cassent), des succès à la con (genre "gagner 100 combats versus d'affilée"), ainsi que l'équilibrage chelou de certaines attaques...
Par exemple le ratio auquel les coups remplissent la jauge de "spécial" adverse en fonction des faibles dégâts distribués - parfois très désavantageux - ou les précieux "Ultras" qu'on imagine dévastateurs, alors qu'ils ne font parfois pas tellement plus mal qu'une attaque forte, ou encore, certains coups spéciaux en quarts de cercle qui ne sont pas dispo partout chez certains persos, alors que la liste de coups (commune à tous) prétend le contraire.
Donc clairement, le jeu est loin d'être parfait, mais on y prend quand même plaisir, et dans la mesure où il est encore en accès anticipé, tout ça me semble relativement pardonnable.

Bref, en l'état, ce [i]Shaolin vs Wutang[/i] est un peu comme un très vieux fantasme sorti de l'enfance qui se réalise, rendant agréablement jouables et affrontables un bon nombre des idoles que je rêvais déraisonnablement de voir un jour réunies dans un même jeu vidéo! Et désormais, étonnamment, ce jeu (certainement très décomplexé sur le plan légal) existe bel et bien... Et pour un prix très abordable qui plus est, compte tenu de son généreux contenu, et de sa réalisation assez honnête à ce tarif.
Je le recommande donc sans hésiter aux amateurs de vieux films de Kung-Fu, qui malgré le très léger fumet d'amateurisme parfois bien perceptible, y trouveront quand même un gigantesque fan service assez inespéré.

29538143.review:
This game really is a love letter to the old Kung Fu movies I remember watching when I was a kid. At the moment of writing the review, there is no singleplayer story mode, but as I understand the developper is working on it. I feel that a story mode would be a GREAT addition to the game in many ways. Among other it would make the characters feel more alive and have greater nostalgia value for the diehard Kung Fu movie fans out there.

The game is nice and fun, characters have different fighting styles. In many ways it reminds me of the old 90s 2D fighting games like Mortal Kombat 3, only that the controls are much more simplistic and the fighting is more realistic (don't expect supernatural abilitys). The special moves have the same key combinations for all the characters, which for me is a good thing. The game is very simple and casual player friendly. As I understand the previous game by the same developer entitled ''Kings of Kung Fu'' is similar in nature but with more challenging gameplay, controls and mechanics.

P.S.: When testing your controls setup be careful not to go into TRAINING mode, because it is meant strictly to train against the dummy or AI - P1vsP2 not supported. Because I didn't know this, I wasted my time trying to set it up for 2 people and even gave the game a negative review. lol

This game kicks ass!  It's not flawless in execution but the concept is great and for an older guy like me that grew up watching old Kung-Fu movies on Saturday morning it's full of nostalgic joy.  I love the music & presentation.  The characters are great (need a Chuck Norris-type of character) and it's great to see so many from classic films.  That's the main draw.  The music, sound effects, and the recognizable fighters will probably appeal more to older player than younger ones as they may not be familiar with the movies referenced here.
The fighting is pretty good.  It's definitely more of a throwback to early 90's fighting games that today's with all the goofy meters and special moves.  It reminds me a bit of Tekken's control scheme but not quite as fluid.  It could use some refining and definitely some more moves.  The music and sounds are mostly great and I like the graphical style.  It's definitely worth more than the price for me as a fan of old Kung-Fu films.  I hope this game continued support and a sequel down the line.  It's the most fun I've had with a fighting game in years.
FLAWS:  Hit detection can be off by a lot at times and the special move doesn't always seem to work evn though the meter is full.

27238051.review:
Like Kings of Kung Fu before it, this is another love letter from Jae Lee to Hong Kong cinema. Where the first film was a playful nod at the Hollywood interpretation of the genre, this goes traditional, with a focus on some of the iconic characters and styles that populated Shaw Brothers and Golden Harvest films since the 60s (saw one reviewer said the 70s, um, you're off a decade - "Come Drink With Me" for example [the spiritual successor to Crouching Tiger and part of the Golden Swallow series]  1966 but some of the first of these films go back to 1949, with movies like "The True Story of Wong Fei-hung".) 

Enough history lesson, now about the game. Shaolin vs. WuTang shows several improvements over Kings of Kung Fu. The controls feel tighter and more responsive, each combatant has an "authentic" weapon associated with the combatant's style of fighting (or in the case of the Silver beared  master [think Pai Mei]) true to the nature of the character protrayed in films. The graphics show a huge improvement over Kings of Kung Fu, which, honestly released only a year ago, shows Jae Lee and his team are getting better. Like KOKF, all the moves are authentic, well animated and with the added bonus of slow motion special effects and a righteous ripped from Hong Kong cinema soundtrack.

Someone complained about the lack of tutorial, and that's a rubbish complaint. Some of the best fighting games didn't have no stinking tutorials. You got a move list card and had to discover and figure it out yourself. Maybe I am showing my age, but have IQs dropped sharply while I was away? You don't need no stinking tutorial, there is a practice mode to hone your chops with and like Street Fighter 2 or Tekken 2, you are thrust into match after match with some character appropriate pre-match banter from the combatants. IMHO, the new frills, clean and focus on fighting is welcome, and if you need a hand holding tutorial, maybe you should go play a Pokemon game or something. FFS.

I am going to be playing this a lot, and look forward to more updates with added stages. While I don't want (and bashed) the tutorial criticism, there is another game I recently discovered (Karate Master 2) that I would love Jae Lee & crew to tackle with a focus on old school Hong Kong cinema given their fighting system, animation style and attention to authentic detail.

If you're knowledge of Hong Kong cinema extends beyond Jackie Chan, Bruce Lee and Donnie Yen, and you know who Gordon Liu, King Hu, Cheng Pei Pei, Chang Cheh, Run Run Shaw,  Feng Lu, Chien Sun aka IRON FEET YANG HU YUN,  Wai Pai and Kuan-Chun Chi are... YOU MUST PICK THIS UP [and also pick up Kings of Kung Fu for some 80s Hollywood kung fu film love)

26579002.review:
Now THAT is what I call a cool game. As a big fan of the good old martial arts movie classics, I instantly had to buy it when I found out about Shaolin vs Wutang. 

The art style is just beautiful, incredibly well done, and when looking at the characters (18 in total and more to come) and their specific Kung Fu styles, I feel like being in one of those kick-♥♥♥ flicks I loved to watch as a kid and now as an adult. And come on, who didn't wish to be able to fight like that? Now here is your chance. Amazing moves are available, worthy of the Golden Harvest era. 

Each and every fighter offers distinctive punches, kicks, and -what's kinda new- also Kung Fu weapons, representing their fraction and style. Of course there are standard & special attacks and combos. 

Precision, distance and timing are rewarded, because you can try to go with spamming buttons, but you'll soon find limits then, especially on higher difficulties. Though there are not that many moves per fighter as in Kings of Kung Fu - which had a ton (also totally worth to get, btw) made by the same dev (nice guy, working hard to even increase the SvW's experience by cool updates), - there are enough, and along with the special attacks a tad easier to pull off, hence a bit less hard to master, but naturally you have to use them wisley to become an real expert in the fantastic arts of Shaolin and Wutang. ;)

If you love Kung Fu, Kung Fu movies and or just superb fighting games with great looking graphics, this game is for you.

Edit: This amazing game gets even better and better - not only with each update - the more you play the less you can't stop, that great are the moves and combos you can use. A real treat. 

It also made me rewatch Ip Man 2, Snake In The Eagle's Shadow, and Drunken Master will be next. More to follow I guess :D

If you like old school classic chinese 70's martial art movies you can't let this game pass by, it's extremely faithfull to the source material and in all aspects a love letter to a cult genre. 

As a fighting game it's in the line of games like tekken, DOA or Bloody Roar, wich i feel strangely similar. The moves are fast, the combos feels rewarding, the animations are really good and visualy it's just stunning, and for me as a KINGS OF KUNG FU player (wich this game is kind of a sequel) i feel a huge improvement in all aspects, although charging it's toll in the character department, wich is a bit smaller and also a little less eclectic, i miss the Karim Abdul, Chuck Norris and Jean Claude Van Damme look-alike characters, they added an exotic flavor wich was much appreciated.

Particullary i like the new combo system that is more intuitive than the character specific target combos from the previous game.

In the sour note, i would say that as the same happened with Kings of Kung fu, i'm not a big fan of fighting ALL the characters in the arcade mode, it turns to be really long, and also, you can't expect the surprise of fighting someone new when you come back with another character, and also, the special moves are a bit hard to pull off when you're not in a combo.

Generally, it's a great game, really fun, at a good price, i would really like to see some tutorials on the combos and maybe character specific moves lists.

24428865.review:
Okay, so I'm a huge fan of Kings of Kung Fu (the first game Jae Lee made). It had a small roster, but fighters with very unique flow, range, and tempo. The fighting styles all played completely differently, the combos were based off of a LK RK, LP RP system. Most of the moves made sense as far as advancing and retreating attacks, it punished you harshly for spamming, and you could flow most of the moves together into free form combos. 
 Shaolin V Wutang however is a huge step back from Kings of Kung Fu. The flow is akward, there is no quick step, all of the moves don't flow into eachother. The left/right system is swapped out for a kick, punch, weapon, roll system(the telegraphed roll, being the only way to change up range quickly). All of this combined makes for a low tempo, stand and combo kind of fighting system. Gone is the constant range manipulation, and fast tempo organic combos from Kings of Kung Fu. 
 Verdict: Buy Kings of Kung Fu, also buy this so Jae makes KOK2.

From the Golden Harvest fight intro, to the represented styles, even the music, Shaolin vs Wu Tang definitely has good flavour.

Gameplay feels a little stiff at first, similar to that of other indy 1v1 kungfuey games. It's not fluid like most of the top tier fighters like mk, sf or doa, but this game is still in development, so I will allow for some wiggle room.

Sound is top tier for those looking to play your fav ol' school kung fu flick. The only thing that would make it better is if they hit up the RZA to do a DLC soundtrack.

The fighter models look fairly simple, but any wuxia film fan will recognize the faces of each style-represented model. Among the few include Jackie, Gordon, Bruce and some older school faves I won't spoil.

The game is quite fun to play...I had a few things to pick up around the house, but insisted on running through the game with Lotus Palm after losing horribly as my boy reppin' the Shaolin long fist. I'd like to see a custom fighter option in the full release as the character roster is only a handfull at this time.

Some costume swaps would be cool, in addition to some more faves:

- Hung Gar Donnie Yen 
- Tai Chi via Jet Li (Twin warriors alt Tai Chi master)
- More from the 5 Deadly Venoms
- Perhaps a represented Michelle Yeoh
- DAVID LO PAN (Big Trouble)

I will keep checking for updates...but any fan of kungfu flicks and fighters should get some fun out of this. 
For a pre-release however, I'd like to see the price drop a little.

-Flu

23141665.review:
[h1]I'm king of nunchucks
I f*cked up Chuck Norris
I invested Jeet Kune Do
So taste my slipper shoe
Here's my two finger push up
Kung F-U (Bruce Lee "ERB") [/h1]

Shaolin vs Wutang - аркадный файтинг в стиле игр 90-х годов, разработчиком которого выступил Jae Lee Production. Внешне игра один в один напомнила мне Kings of Kung Fu. Но в отличие от Kings of Kung Fu в Shaolin vs Wutang берут участие только азиатские бойцы.

Сюжета здесь вы не увидите, просто очередной турнир, основанный чтобы выявить лучшего среди лучших. Из знакомых нам лиц вы сможете увидеть Брюса Ли, Джеки Чана, Джета Ли и многих других. Каждый из бойцов отличается своим уникальным боевым стилем и возможностью воспользоваться персональным оружием. Допустим, у Брюса Ли - это, конечно же, нунчаки. То есть вы сможете сделать неплохую связку ударов, начиная бить соперника руками и закончить начатое нунчаками. Напомню что игра находиться в раннем доступе, и, скорее всего, разработчики добавят еще очень много игрового контента.

Геймплей, как и в большинства файтингах, прост до невозможности. Жми все подряд кнопки и надейся на удачную связку приемов своего бойца) Здесь нет каких-то спецприемов или суперударов, как в том же Наруто или МК. Боевая система максимально приближена к жизни. Тренируйтесь в свободном режиме чтобы пройти игру на максимальной сложности, или попытайтесь сразиться со своим другом по локальной сети. Как я и упомянул ранее игра уж очень похожа на Kings of Kung Fu как и стилистикой, так и боевкой. Поначалу я уж подумал что это продолжение этой серии. Но нет, это отдельная игра. Хотелось бы отметить, единственное что отличает эти творение - это то, что в Shaolin vs Wutang присутствует возможность взять в руки оружие.

Внешне игра очень красива. Если вы любитель фильмов о боевых искусствах, то игра вам явно понравится. Живой бэкграунд, выполненный в добрых традициях азиатского кинематографа 80-90х годов, особенно порадовал. Звуковая составляющая полностью дополняет визуальный ряд. Я бы даже сказал, что графика и звуковое сопровождение - есть неотъемлемой частью игрового процесса.

К большому сожалению, ничего, кроме простых боев мы здесь не увидим. Никаких дополнительных режимов или возможной гонки лидеров по времени. Хотелось бы, конечно, написать больше об этом продукте, но попросту писать нечего.

Под конец обзора перечислим плюсы и минусы проекта.

Плюсы:
+ Боевая система максимально приближена к жизни
+ Красочные пейзажи 
+ Каждый боец с уникальным стилем кунг фу
+ Графическая и звуковая составляющие переносят нас в азиатский кинематограф

Минусы:
- Большое сходство с Kings of Kung Fu
- Небольшое количество играбельных персонажей
- Отсутствие соревновательного режима

Shaolin vs Wutang - довольно неплохой аркадный файтинг, выполненный в стиле азиатских фильмов 80-90х годов. Даю этому проекту 6 из 10.

"Окей, выбираю Брюса Ли. Сейчас я покажу вам кунг фу! После 20 ударов пропущенных от Джеки Чана, понимаю что кунг фу - это не мое"

[b][i] *За этот обзор я благодарен разработчику, который предоставил ключ от данной игры. Однако это никак не повлияло на мой личный взгляд на проект. [/i][/b]

22968733.review:
対戦格闘アクションゲーム。
開発元が『Kings of Kung Fu』と同じ。
やっている事もほとんど同じ。
違いは『KoK』のキャラクターが世界の格闘アクション俳優だったのが、香港映画に絞られている事と、操作が簡略化された事。
それと、当たり判定や動きのバグがかなり減った事と、キャラクターの絵がかなりまともになった事が目立った点。

と言う事で・・・。
何処かで見たようなキャラクターたちが、何処かで見たようなステージで、何処かで聞いたようなBGMの中で格闘するゲーム。
大昔やった、『少林寺三十六房』、『酔拳』ごっこをPCの中でやるゲーム。
飛び蹴りと共に「アチャァァァァァ！」と近所迷惑にならない程度に叫ぶゲーム。

『KoK』との違い
操作は攻撃（武器、手、足）と回避と方向ボタンだけで行う。
攻撃の種類はレバー入れでほとんど全員共通。
ダッシュは無いので回避で代用。
大振り攻撃を防御する時は避ける動作になり、反撃が早く出る。

結論：『KoK』よりかなり良い。

After watching the trailers of this game and the beta footage, I was immediately psyched when I found out another version of this game was being made. I'm a huge fan of the old Chinese martial arts films and so naturally, I want to try this game out and after a while of playing, I was very impressed with the level of authenticity with the character models and the levels in the game. I truly hope the developer will keep adding to this one...

The graphics for this game really grabbed me, especially the feel of the old movies that I grew up watching... just turn on the movie effect and you are pretty close to watching the movie, especially on stages like Waterfall. I almost just want to stand there an admire the details. If you are on a stronger machine, you can turn on everything and truly experience the game.

The character models all feel familiar. I instantly recognised the influences for the character, especially The Dragon and White Brow, with his signature smug pose. I almost wanted him to laugh at me as he was whupping my ass, just like the movies. The animation at times feels very fluid during the fight and each strike and kick feels and sounds just like the movies, but I wish there were more moves for these guys and a movelist for each character. I had to figure out the moves at first but after a round, I caught on quickly. On the other hand, there is a little stiffness with some of the movements but I am sure after an update, it will be fixed. 

In closing of this review, the developer has put a lot of love and energy into creating a game that feels like the genuine article. And as a fan of martial arts, I deeply appreciate the love and care that has been taken to create interesting characters and picturesque environment (Btw, the market stage is pretty cool too. The dog doesn't even know the fight is going on, lol), and it just grabs you. If you have played the previous entry, Kings of Kung Fu, you will definitely love this one... #TeamWutang

22899928.review:
If you are a fan of martial arts films, you are really going to enjoy Shaolin vs Wutang.

A few minutes into this game and I was hooked. I couldn't believe that for early access there is so much more accomplished here than in Kings of Kung Fu. The dev definitely improved his skill since then and it shows.

The visuals are absolutely beautiful. Some of the stages just blew me away with the detail that during the fights I found myself focusing more on the environment than the actual fight.
Adding to the awesome experience, I was really impressed with the music and sound fx. It just adds that much more to the experience making it feel like you are taking part in a 1970's Kung Fu film.

I'm in total shock that this is all done by one dev. I have to take my hat off to him. This is super impressive work.

Now being an early access game I did expect to find some issues in the game. I noticed graphical glitches very rarely appearing throughout the game (sometimes at random or sometimes when changing the graphics settings), I also noticed character clipping when they were too close to each other, and an imbalanced AI fighting system. There were a few other bugs but nothing serious.

Closing this up, all I can say is this game is definitely worth the $$$ and is an experience you should not miss. The dev put a lot of heart into it and as an early access game it's great to be a part of it to watch it get better with the patches and updates.

This is definitely a game I will be playing quite often. You should give it a try too. :)

22895861.review:
This game is a far improved offering over the dev's other game, Kings of Kung Fu. Where the other game fell short in execution and delivery, this game has largely fixed and it now actually feels like there is a solid engine and framework in place. While its DEFINITELY NOT a game catering to the hardcore FGC crowd, the important tropes that must exist do exist (such as deep jump ins, crossups, pokes, footsies, etc). 

'Execution requirements' is not even a thought. The game was never intended to be something you need a bible and 3 years of college to become good at a single character... Its a game where you can pick up and have fun pulling off cool moves. A basic overarching yet simple moveset links everything together and allows you to recreate moments from the old classic kung fu movies which the game takes its inspirations from with very little difficulty. However 'simple' does not mean 'baselessly shallow' like the previous game. This game does have enough depth to it to reward those who absolutely insist on getting the last 20% out of a character, as opposed to simply playing to 80%. Its simple, and yet rewarding.

The game still has a number of kinks and flaws of course but it IS Early Access. Give it a chance to develop as it is a labor of love by a single guy.

比起上一次的Kings of Kungfu明显有进步。缺点也很明显。

+怀旧感十足
+华丽的招式
+虚心听取玩家意见并改进的创作态度
+终于支持简体中文了
+终于听到经典BGM将军令了

-BGM不够激昂
-判定略奇怪
-招式不够丰富

-优化略差，偶尔卡顿跳bug

当然，光有情怀还不够，好作品仍需打磨。这只是抢先体验版，相信后续的版本会更好。

作为格斗游戏，手感略生硬。作为业余小制作的小品游戏，质量相当高。

数十个来自功夫片的角色，就算没看过也有听说过，即使叫不出名字也有印象。

作者总是在第一时间解答玩家提出的疑问，并且针对玩家的意见建议进行改进，这种创作态度值得肯定！

游戏时不时会有各种大大小小的更新，可以肯定的是，这个游戏会随着时间的推移，内容将越来越丰富，玩法将越来越多样。

40613759.review:
Pues a mí me ha gustado por varias razones:

- La primera es un poco lo que vienen diciendo otros análisis: Representa muy bien las películas de artes marciales "chinas" (Ahora explico las comillas) de los años 80. Han hecho un juego muy sobrio y realista que si ves los movimientos cualquiera puede pensar que alguien con un mínimo de preparación e interés puede ejecutarlos, incluso los especiales.
- No se fliparon metiendo bolas de energía, patadas de fuego, elevaciones a 40 metros de una patada o fuegos artificiales cada vez que metes un golpe medio raro, lo cual veo en otros juegos de lucha mucho más populares y eso en el Street Fighter, vale, tiene un pase porque es un poco marca de la casa desde que yo era pequeño, pero en sitios como Tekken sobran y mucho (Y os lo dice uno que es fan del 7 y le da al online duro). Aquí han ido a lo realista y yo me creería que las peleas en China puedan ser así. 
- Están mimando muchísimo el juego. Yo creo que los desarrolladores saben que no es un juego para todos los públicos pero quieren mimar a la gente que hemos mostrado interés en el juego, lo cual, yo como usuario se lo agradezco mucho, como dato: Cuando lo compré iba un poco a ciegas pero me gustaba la temática. Me encontré 20 luchadores (Contando al ninja y al americano) y más bien poco que hacer fuera de un modo arcade que se acababa haciendo un poco largo, pero ahora lo he retomado y me he encontrado 30 luchadores (Ver a gente de capoeira, kickboxing o un inglés claramente inspirado en Chuck Norris es muy refrescante, entre otras novedades), otros tantos escenarios, creo también que aumentaron las conversaciones personales (Dependiendo a quien te enfrentes tu luchador le puede dar un trato especial), le pusieron un breve argumento que explica porqué se están dando de palos (El alemán del kickboxing me recordó muchísimo a Jean Claude Van Damme en Contacto Sangriento así como su combate final) y en general, no sé lo que tienen pensado meter en un futuro. 

También tiene puntos a mejorar, pero al ser un early access, entiendo que aún les queda tiempo pero lo están haciendo bien, aunque podrían mejorar:

- El online: Lo veo un poco cutre plantarte una clasificación de los mejores y arreando, me imagino que eso lo mejorarán poniendo rangos o cualquier otra cosa que le de vidilla.
- Pocos golpes por luchador. Se me olvidó decir que la plantilla de 30 que ahora tiene se aprecian mucho las diferencias entre unos y otros, pero tal vez eso haya ido en detrimento de recortar el repertorio de golpes por cada PJ.
- Las animaciones si acaso un poco toscas.

Resumen: No me arrepiento de haberlo comprado en early access, veo que le están metiendo contenido nuevo y me gustaría ver lo que sale de ahí.

40560720.review:
I usually don't structure reviews like this, but I'm going to list off games that come to mind/I'm reminded of and the element of them before I talk about this game

Dead or Alive-The Approach to doing specific grabs at precise times and the approach to movement in terms of dogding and blocking remind me of dead or allives approach as well as a light approach to DOA's destrctilble elements, obviously wthout all the fan service and whatnot

Killer Instinct-Although a tad watered down/tad slower (which is not a bad thing, just for the record) The game's pace and speed reminds me of KI

Street Fighter-Each character has their own stage and music

Mortal Kombat-The game is hard and at times can be very challenging, sometimes to the point of being a tad unfair with how hard, however the AI is not cheap, it's just that the AI can be relentless on the tougher difficulties

Deadliest Warrior-This is the biggest "contender" this game can compare to. What does this and Shaolin vs Wutang have in common? Both appear generic at first, but I assure you, don't judge a book by it's cover, because like Deadliest Warrior, despite looking generic at first and having a focus on public domain in regard to characters, it makes suprisingly good use and execution in terms of fighting styles/playstyles and variety when it comes to the characters. Despite the characters not being memorable, they play and feel well and different and are implemented well

Now, let's get to what makes the game fun, but also it's problems

(Bear in mind this was played using a logitech gamepad controller, so it may slightly vary depending on how you play and with what)

Shaolin vs Wutang is a fun game overall, but not without it's problems and gripes

Whilst the gameplay is fun and all, the problems I had will also be listed as were the positives/reminders

Balancing-Whilst the game is for the most part balanced I genrally do fairly well at fighting games, and while the challenge is nice, I feel as thouh the game suffers a bit of diffculty problems that Payday 2 has (Payday 2 may be a different game entirely, but just hear me out) as both games have somewhat of a gap issue when it comes to difficulties (to compare, death wish and one down/death sentence have a difficulty gap problem, and in this game that applies to normal and hard, normal is a challenge, but I often had close matches on normal and would almost run out of time during some matches, which is a bit unbalanced, the game is mostly balanced, but could use a tad of fixing

Controls-The controls aren't bad, but they aren't great either and it does take reading for this one as well as getting used to. At first glance this may seem like common sense, but when you (meaning people in general) play enough fighters, you can get a basic idea of what the buttons do and how controls work without training and then what you do use training for is to learn intricacies and the ins and outs. Its also not said on how to throw/grab and in turn not how to grab escape. To my knowledge there also isn't a tutorial (correct me if I'm wrong on the no tutorial thing) there is a control list/move list, which does help, but a tutorial to master mechanics and understand how the game plays in depth can help MAJORLY

The game's controls do work, but I will warn all of you that the game feels and functions better using the ANALOG STICK rather than the D-pad (big letters-emphasis) as you can tell there is less delay on actions, attacks, and movement using the analog stick, which needs to be adressed. Also, jumping can be a bit finicky, sometimes you may jump without moving when you were trying to move to the left or right for example, whilst this isn't a gamebreaker it does need to be adressed


Music-I feel bad that the tracks are licensed from kung fu movies, now before anyone jumps at this point, just hear me out

On one end I have not seen many kung fu movies, (which I do want to fix) however most of the music aside from maybe 3 tracks are too short and keep looping and are kind of bland and generic, why I feel bad is because the guy behind the game had to pay fees for the music and it wasn't that appealing. I also hope this game in the future doesn't suffer the fate of Alan Wake (which for those that don't know, was removed due to soundtrack licensing expiring, that also can be said for Driver San Francisco for another example) However one element I will give the music credit about is that it's cheesy and generic feel does at least fit well with the game (in other words, this game  is a giant homage to kung fu movies, and these tracks do fit the vibes the game tries to give off)


Now, let's get to the positives

Roster-The roster is very varied, fun, and diverse, although the characters may not look that great in design terms as mentined beforehand, each one plays very differently and in fun ways, not to mention more characters are getting added for free via updates, which is generous and a nice touch.

Combat-I like the idea of weapons being mapped to the X button, whilst b and a are for your different attack types (punches and kicks). All the attacks overall flow fairly well. The other elment to keep in mind or make note of is how attack "weight" for lack of a better term is handled. Whilst holding back either left or right (depending on which side you are facing) determines your attack type (light medium or heavy) which is not necessarily groundbreaking, but it is different and executed fairly well. The dashing mechanic is also a nice change of pace and can help to give yourself distance or to close distance. Whilst dashing in itself is nothing new for fighters, what is is how it's done, which is by using Y. Some people may like or dislike it, but I personally enjoyed it, it just takes getting used to

Challenge-Despite the minor balancing issues that need to be adressed, the game is overall a good challenge and deffinately will require you to make good use of each fighters different moves and move types and the AI can put you on your feet at times


Now lastly, here's the things I would change or "neutral" points about the game

Ladder Selection-One problem I had was I felt the game lasted a bit too long for one sitting. I personally would either make it so you can save mid ladder (just start back at the postion in arcade mode you were at, just at round one, only losing individual round progress) or take a page from mortal kombat and allow you to pick your ladder length, such as short, medium, large, extra large etc...

Difficulty-This is more so a warning to people, but bear in mind for whatever reason that the game is by default set to HARD (I don't know why) so to fairly judge it/give it a try, you will need to set it to normal, however this does need to be fixed

Alternative Soundtrack-For when the licensing eventually expires, there should be another soundtrack with orignal songs to avoid any issues

Overall, Shaolin vs Wutang does have it's problems and places it needs to be fixed, however you should still keep in mind that where the game succeeds is the most important elments, that being the flow, combat/feel and roster, which imo are the most important elments of a fighting game, and these reasons are why you should give it a try, don't expect anything groundbreaking, but expect something fun, and something different.

Hopefully the developer Jae Lee reads this, and my advice to you if you read this Jae, add yourself as a character for kicks/fun, and be sure to update the game/patch it with it's problems and work on alternative music, because tbh the game has potential to be great, it's just currently its slightly above average at its current state

40196853.review:
Jim "Black Belt Jones" Kelly versus Jean Claude Van Damme, Chuck Norris versus Jackie Chan, Bolo Yeung versus Donnie Yen... who would win? I'd say it would be everybody with the indie game, Shaolin Versus Wutang.

If you ever wanted to see who would come out on top in a grudge match between your favorite marital arts actors of yesteryear, well now you can.

The controls are simple but not so much that the gameplay becomes a button mashy mess. That being said, I'm fond of the technical old-school games like Capcom Vs. SNK, and this game doesn't come close to that level of complexity. That said, it doesn't really need to. It's clear that Shaolin Versus Wutang is a love letter to the chop-socky flicks of yore. This game nails the setting and feeling of these films.

The sound effects and soundtrack are well selected. They really evoke the feeling of sitting down to watch Drunken Master.

Now, instead of injuring your wrist trying to do those wrist push-ups Jackie Chan did in the film, or breaking your lamp in the living room during Bloodsport with an overexuberant sidekick, you can do so from the comfort of your computer chair.

Though, I admit, this game probably won't stop me from breaking light fixtures or injuring myself during a kung-fu movie super marathon.

Developer Jae Lee has done a remarkable job here. Highly recommended. So much fun.

39981478.review:
Whoever made this should have spent less time trying to make 40 characters that barely function and SHOULD have spent their time working toward making TWO characters that actually control well. This feels like a flash game.

I'm starting to think the reviews are fake because there's a 5-10 minute load time, You can't jump forwards or backwards without doing a hadouken motion from forward to up. If you just press a diagonal direction ,the character just jumps upwards.

The frames break CONSTANTLY. The loading takes 5-10 minutes on a computer that can run any 2018 game on full blast with zero slowdown. It's just a buggy mess! The sound effects clip each other out, so you'll hear the first milisecond of a punch effect over and over if you mash the punch button.

There's no dashing. Instead you get a "Dodge" that's "Invunerable (only to the first standing weapon attack in a chain)" for 16 frames. So if you want to...I don't know, move closer? You have to walk. Which is slow enough that anybody can see and react with a sweep. 

This game was so bad that not only do I want my $9 back, I want my $9 and $30 extra for a bottle of whiskey to wash the taste out. Early access or not, you can tell that it's pretty much a form over function setup. They've spent more time adding a bunch of needless stuff when the basic stuff the game shipped with doesn't even function properly to begin with.
39981478.developer_response:
Just wanted to clarifty a few things. The Inital load time is kind of long but not 5-10 minutes long more like 2 minutes. I decided that it would be better to have a longer load at the beginning of the game in order to provide a better experience with shorter load times once you're playing the game. I'll probably change this with a patch soon, so that the Initial first boot up load is shorter, but the in game loading time is slightly longer. Secondly the controls are simplified. The control limitations are a constraint of the engine unfortunately. This game is designed for casual players not hardcore fighting game enthusiast . It's a passion project not a AAA fighting game.

It is important to note as well that this game is not designed or targeted towards seasoned or hardcore fighting game players. Its designed for Casual fans and mainly fans of martial arts and martial arts films. This was a intentional decision knowing the limitations of the engine im using. Most of my target audience won't know or care about the things that you're focused on like dashing, or defense on wakeup. Trust me my friend if I had the ability to make a fighter using a professional fighting engine I would jump at the opportunity. Hopefully I will have the chance in the future if this little game does well enough.

 I appreciate the feedback and your review :)
